comment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/review/show/1260456768?book_show_action=false\u0026amp;from_review_page=10\"\u003esee review\u003c/a\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n    \u003cdiv id='comments_for_review_1260456768' style='display: none;'\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment'\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"loadingLink\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/review/1260456768/comments?reverse=true\"\u003eView 1 comment\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1260456768' style='display: none'\u003e\n\u003ctextarea class='placeholder_text' onclick=\"expand_comment_form_for('review', 1260456768, true, '')\"\u003eWrite a comment...\u003c/textarea\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\n      \u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"elementListBrownSeparator\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"friendReviews elementListBrown\" \u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"section\"\u003e\n      \n\n\u003cdiv id=\"review_732619942\" class=\"review\" itemprop=\"reviews\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Review\"\u003e\n  \u003clink itemprop=\"url\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/732619942\" /\u003e\n    \u003ca title=\"Deborah Markus\" class=\"left imgcol\" href=\"/user/show/954028-deborah-markus\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Deborah Markus\" src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442990055p2/954028.jpg\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"left bodycol\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"reviewHeader uitext stacked\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/732619942?book_show_action=false\"\u003eAug 06, 2014\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Deborah Markus\" class=\"user\" name=\"Deborah Markus\" href=\"/user/show/954028-deborah-markus\"\u003eDeborah Markus\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003ereally liked it\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n          \u003cspan class=\"greyText\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\n          \u003ca class=\"lightGreyText\" title=\"Hardcover 9780747532699\" href=\"/book/show/848654.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone\"\u003ereview of another edition\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\n        \n\n\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer732619942\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer17859498857687804644\"\u003eI'm the only person in the world with \u003ci\u003emixed\u003c/i\u003e feelings about the Harry Potter books. Most readers love them. There are non-readers who are indifferent to them as they are to all other books; others who go solely by the fact that they're \"children's\" books and therefore believe it's ridiculous for adults to read and enjoy them; and of course a legion of similarly anti-literacy folk who have decided the Harry Potter books are immoral. These people, who read and enjoy Tolkien, C.S. Lewis, and stories\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText17859498857687804644\" style=\"display:none\"\u003eI'm the only person in the world with \u003ci\u003emixed\u003c/i\u003e feelings about the Harry Potter books. Most readers love them. There are non-readers who are indifferent to them as they are to all other books; others who go solely by the fact that they're \"children's\" books and therefore believe it's ridiculous for adults to read and enjoy them; and of course a legion of similarly anti-literacy folk who have decided the Harry Potter books are immoral. These people, who read and enjoy Tolkien, C.S. Lewis, and stories about Merlin and King Arthur, have concluded that the Potter universe is an evil place because it has magic and witches. All righty, then. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI suppose there are readers who genuinely dislike the Harry Potter books. I haven't come across them, but they must be out there \u003ci\u003esomewhere.\u003c/i\u003e And of course there must be readers who \u003ci\u003esay\u003c/i\u003e they dislike them when what they mean is, they're wildly jealous that they didn't write them.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI don't belong in any of those categories. I admire the fine writing, characterization, dialogue, and world-building Rowling has done. And exactly because her writing is so good, the one flaw I've found pains me to the point that I can't read these with the pure pleasure they give so many others.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThe only person I've talked to about this who's been willing to listen long enough to understand what I'm saying is the one person I know who hasn't read the books and has no plans to. He thinks I make a valid point. \u003ci\u003eEveryone else\u003c/i\u003e I've attempted to engage on this topic has responded, \"You're saying something bad about Harry Potter. You must be bad. I hate you. Please leave my home.\" Or words to that effect. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI'll grant you that accepting flaws in things we love is a little-taught skill in this world. It's almost as rare as seeing good qualities in those we hate. This is as true with books as it is with people, and it's tragic. I have yet to meet someone who can acknowledge the admirable qualities of books they can't stand. I don't mean genuinely bad books, the kind that will be pulped a year after they were printed (if they last that long) or that will never make it to paper in the first place not because technology is awesome but because *nobody* wants to waste the paper on these works. No, I mean books that have stood the test of time but who have as many haters as lovers.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003ePerfect example: \u003ci\u003eLittle Women.\u003c/i\u003e People adore this book, or they despise it.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eListen up: \"Little Women\" is corny, mawkish, and sentimental. It's also wise, funny, and strong. Whether you like the book or you hate it, if you can't admit that \u003ci\u003eall of this is true\u003c/i\u003e and this can all be true \u003ci\u003eat the same time about the same book,\u003c/i\u003e you have a serious ego problem. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eYou can't admit that the book you love could have \u003ci\u003eanything\u003c/i\u003e wrong with it. (\"Krinkle, krinkle, 'ittle 'tar\"? Really? That's not cringe-inducing? Calling a grown woman \"Marmee\" isn't cringe-inducing? Having the one black child at Jo's school for boys be the best singer isn't \u003ci\u003eseriously\u003c/i\u003e cringe-inducing?). Or else you refuse to entertain the idea that anything you hate could have anything \u003ci\u003eright\u003c/i\u003e about it. (Marmee's advice to Meg about the difference between the flashing tempers of the March girls and the temperament of the man Meg married stands the test of time \u003ci\u003every\u003c/i\u003e well, as do plenty of the other observations of humanity -- when Jo laughingly admits that she's well enough to go on a carriage ride with Laurie, but not well enough to do disagreeable chores, and then karma kicks her in the arse. Which it tends to do a lot in this book.)\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003ePut your ego aside when thinking about and discussing literature. Good books are not saints. They should be admired, enjoyed, learned from, and reread; but they should also be critically examined. And if I've done all that with the Harry Potter books \u003ci\u003eand\u003c/i\u003e I've found something I think is a serious flaw, it would be nice to be able to \u003ci\u003ediscuss\u003c/i\u003e that, rather than be glared and yelled at (yes, both have happened, and yes, I'm still angry) because I have the unmitigated gall to find something wrong with Saint Jo.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eFor anyone who's still reading: I'm very uncomfortable with one aspect of the world Rowling has created. Specifically, I don't think her justification for hiding the existence of magic from the world of ordinary humans stands up well in a court of ethics.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThis is a review of the first book, so I'll only go into what she says here. When Harry Potter first learns who is parents really are, Hagrid is furious at the Dursleys for not having told him anything about what he calls Harry's world. \u003ci\u003e\"Our\u003c/i\u003e world, I mean. \u003ci\u003eYour\u003c/i\u003e world. \u003ci\u003eMy\u003c/i\u003e world. Yer parents' world.\" \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIt's terribly wrong not to have told Harry who and what he is, and who and what his parents were. Agreed. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eHow, then, is it all right to hide what is, after all, the \u003ci\u003ereal\u003c/i\u003e world from the majority of its inhabitants? \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eHow is it all right to scorn them for not having magic while at the same time doing everything to keep them from knowing magic exists?\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eDon't say there's no scorn. \"Muggle\" is hardly a term of endearment. (Yes, I'm jumping ahead of myself and I promised I wouldn't, but \"mud-blood\" is nothing but an extension of the condescension contained in \"Muggle.\") And as for the attitude towards the mundane world, look at Hagrid -- one of the good guys, certainly, and a very appealing character:\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\"Although Hagrid seemed to know where he was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary way. He got stuck in the ticket barrier on the Underground and complained loudly that the seats were too small and the trains too slow.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e'I don't know how the Muggles manage without magic,' he said, as they climbed a broken-down escalator.\"\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eWe manage because you won't let us do otherwise. And then you sneer at the job we do.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eLet me ask you something: Do you really believe that \"separate but equal\" can be both? That's not how it works in the real world, and it's not how it works in Potter's world. The magical beings there are an elite minority, and they like it that way. They have the power. They're hanging on to it by force (more about that in later books), even when that puts the inhabitants of the mundane world at risk (WAY more about that in later books).\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eLet me ask you something else: If you read and enjoy Austen's novels in the way that many people do -- taking pleasure in imagining yourself a member of that world -- you imagine yourself as one of the genteel, right? Not one of the servants. We see very little of them, and they have miserable lives. The power situation in Austen's time was horribly imbalanced and unfair. Austen wasn't in much of a position to do anything about it; but at least she didn't have her characters brag all the time about how awesome it was to be of the land-owning class, and how pathetic those stupid servants are.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIn fact, the one character I can think of who \u003ci\u003edoes\u003c/i\u003e complain about servants is Aunt Norris, and she's an out-and-out villain. Her observations on the serving class are meant to reinforce just what a nasty piece of work she is.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eOne person I know claimed that in the Potter universe, the magic-users keep their existence and powers a secret in order to protect themselves. That's contradicted later -- I think in book #3, in which Harry reads a textbook about how much real witches enjoy being burned at the stake because it tickles and doesn't do them any harm -- but for now I'll just point out what Hagrid says when Harry asks why the Ministry of Magic \"keeps it from the Muggles that there's still witches an' wizards up an' down the country.\"\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\"Blimey, Harry, everyone'd be wantin' magic solutions to their problems. Nah, we're best left alone.\"\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIf Rowling wanted to make a universe in which a failed attempt had been made in the past to live on equal terms with the non-magic world, and that attempt had led to great suffering and many lives lost on \u003ci\u003eboth\u003c/i\u003e sides, that would be perfectly tenable. (And fascinating. Somebody, write that book. Okay, I will.) If she wanted to claim that magic-users would be persecuted by the ordinary humans, and the magicians might have the magic but the mundane world had the sheer numbers and a lot of nasty technology on their side, \u003ci\u003ethat\u003c/i\u003e would certainly work. And then I could read these books without a qualm.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eInstead, she's created a world in which a ruling class cheerfully admits that they \u003ci\u003elike\u003c/i\u003e having all the really cool stuff and they're jolly well not going to share with those foolish mortals who are so stupid, they have to struggle up broken escalators.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eWhat troubles me even more than her making this decision (which, as I've pointed out, is \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e the only way to go if you want to have a world of hidden magic) is how enthusiastically her readers have embraced it. There are \"No Muggles Allowed\" posters and Facebook pages. Created and enjoyed by people who don't seem to realize that, just as they'd more likely be a servant than gentility in Austen's world, odds are good they'd be Muggles in Rowling's. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003ePeople who have felt odd and left out all their lives naturally embrace the idea that secretly, they're special and strong -- magical, even. I only question the idea that having wonderful abilities has to go hand in hand with lording it over those who don't. How is the Potter universe's attitude toward non-magic users any different from Malfoy's gloating over his entirely inherited monetary wealth, and sneering at Ron's poverty?\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI'm very uncomfortable with the Potter universe because I don't have the ego to believe I'd be one of the special ones. I'm rereading these with my son because he doesn't remember them very well and his grandmother kindly lent us an entire hardcover library of the British editions. This journey has its pleasures, but it's the last I'll take to the Potter world. It's no place for Muggles.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eUPDATE: I'm now about a hundred pages into the British edition of the last Harry Potter book, and I'm already seriously considering rereading the whole series just to have the entire, incredibly complex plot fresh in my head for once. Yes, the things that bug me philosophically about this series still bother me; but the writing is just too good for even cranky old me to resist. \u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"17859498857687804644\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n          \u003c/span\u003e\n        \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n       \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer1458115397\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer3340167781694670547\"\u003eThe audio book was a whole new class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"elementListBrownSeparator\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"friendReviews elementListBrown\" \u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"section\"\u003e\n      \n\n\u003cdiv id=\"review_1589157781\" class=\"review\" itemprop=\"reviews\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Review\"\u003e\n  \u003clink itemprop=\"url\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1589157781\" /\u003e\n    \u003ca title=\"Nashali Torres\" class=\"left imgcol\" href=\"/user/show/46607911-nashali-torres\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Nashali Torres\" src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442102980p2/46607911.jpg\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"left bodycol\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"reviewHeader uitext stacked\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/1589157781?book_show_action=false\"\u003eMar 25, 2016\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Nashali Torres\" class=\"user\" name=\"Nashali Torres\" href=\"/user/show/46607911-nashali-torres\"\u003eNashali Torres\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n          \u003cspan class=\"greyText\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\n          \u003ca \u003cdiv class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/46607911-nashali-torres?shelf=favs-forever-in-love\"\u003efavs-forever-in-love\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/46607911-nashali-torres?shelf=2016\"\u003e2016\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer1589157781\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer3145819570407059159\"\u003eBrillante!!! ¿Por qué no había leído Harry Potter antes? \u003c/span\u003e\n\n          \u003c/span\u003e\n        \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n      \u003cdiv class=\"reviewFooter uitext buttons\"\u003e\n          \n\n\u003ctr class=\"no_border feedFooterReview\" id=\"update_comment_stuff_Review1589157781\"\u003e\n  \u003ctd colspan=\"2\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"updateActionLinks\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"right flag\" rel=\"nofollow\" id=\"flag_link1589157781\" title=\"Flag this review as inappropriate.\" href=\"/flagged/new?resource_id=1589157781\u0026amp;resource_type=Review\u0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone\"\u003eflag\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\n\n\n\n      \u003cspan class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1589157781'\u003e\u003ca id=\"like_count_review_1589157781\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"/rating/voters/1589157781?resource_type=Review\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"likesCount\"\u003e17 likes\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003cspan class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca id=\"like_action_review_1589157781\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-like-container-id=\"like_container_review_1589157781\" ref=\"like\" class=\"jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink\" data-remote=\"true\" data-method=\"post\" href=\"/rating?count_on_right=false\u0026amp;format=json\u0026amp;lc=17\u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=10\u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1589157781\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review\"\u003eLike\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca id=\"commentLink_1589157781\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"comment_form_for(\u0026#39;review\u0026#39;, 1589157781, true, \u0026#39;\u0026#39;); return false;\"\u003e1 comment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/review/show/1589157781?book_show_action=false\u0026amp;from_review_page=10\"\u003esee review\u003c/a\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n    \u003cdiv id='comments_for_review_1589157781' style='display: none;'\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment'\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"loadingLink\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/review/1589157781/comments?reverse=true\"\u003eView 1 comment\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1589157781' style='display: none'\u003e\n\u003ctextarea class='placeholder_text' onclick=\"expand_comment_form_for('review', 1589157781, true, '')\"\u003eWrite a comment...\u003c/textarea\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer201711823\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer10024032622645292111\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eHP is my number one book series for a reread!\u003c/b\u003e \u003cbr\u003eReading \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone\" title=\"Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e is like meeting an old friend. It never gets old and I'll never get tired of reading it!\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cb\u003e“There are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.” \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eYou can't help falling in love with reading after discovering the Harry Potter series as a young reader. This is the magical place where book worms are born!!HP turns reluctant reade\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText10024032622645292111\" style=\"display:none\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eHP is my number one book series for a reread!\u003c/b\u003e \u003cbr\u003eReading \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone\" title=\"Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e is like meeting an old friend. It never gets old and I'll never get tired of reading it!\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cb\u003e“There are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.” \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eYou can't help falling in love with reading after discovering the Harry Potter series as a young reader. This is the magical place where book worms are born!!HP turns reluctant readers into series bookworms and devourers of book series, and this is true for my eleven year old daughter. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eI began reading the Harry Potter series to her two years ago and she quickly fell in love with the HP world and characters. She laughed, cried, celebrated with and cheered for HP and his friends. She can even remember the names of each of the characters in the whole series! \u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449228485i/17254088._SX540_.png\" class=\"gr-hostedUserImg\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eReading Harry Potter has opened up a world of books for her and now she's reading \u003cb\u003eGail carriger's\u003c/b\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/20980648.Waistcoats___Weaponry__Finishing_School___3_\" title=\"Waistcoats \u0026amp; Weaponry (Finishing School, #3) by Gail Carriger\"\u003eWaistcoats \u0026amp; Weaponry\u003c/a\u003e book three in the \u003cb\u003eFinishing School series\u003c/b\u003e and she has already finished reading \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/337537.The_Naughtiest_Girl_in_the_School__The_Naughtiest_Girl___1_\" title=\"The Naughtiest Girl in the School (The Naughtiest Girl, #1) by Enid Blyton\"\u003eThe Naughtiest Girl in the School\u003c/a\u003e series, a few YA (middle grade) paranormal books, \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7938275.The_Hunger_Games_Trilogy_Boxset__The_Hunger_Games___1_3_\" title=\"The Hunger Games Trilogy Boxset (The Hunger Games, #1-3) by Suzanne Collins\"\u003eThe Hunger Games Trilogy Boxset\u003c/a\u003e and my YA horror book \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7619057.Warm_Bodies__Warm_Bodies___1_\" title=\"Warm Bodies (Warm Bodies, #1) by Isaac Marion\"\u003eWarm Bodies\u003c/a\u003e, and she loved it! I think my little bookworm is about to raid my stash of books and I better move my romance/grown up books out of the way until she's a bit older.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449228485ra/17254089.gif\" class=\"gr-hostedUserImg\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eOnce again, I finished reading \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone\" title=\"Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e but this time I read it with my nine year old son. He's a reluctant reader who loves the outdoors and computer games so I decided to use HP to improve his reading skills and perhaps help him discover love of books.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449232455i/17254389._SY540_.jpg\" class=\"gr-hostedUserImg\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eHe loves watching the HP movies (only the first three) but this is the first time he has read \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone\" title=\"Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e and he tells me the book is better than the movie! I'm so proud of him! He's upset the movies left out Peeves the Poltergeist, the prankster ghost and his new favourite character. He's already quoting The Philosopher's Stone (and he's adding a few twists of his own) and it's pretty funny and adorable! \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449229702i/17254195._SX540_.jpg\" class=\"gr-hostedUserImg\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eWe've already started \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets\u003c/a\u003e, It's going to take us a long time to finish the HP series but it'll all be worth it in the end. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eAlready a new generation is discovering the phenomenal, magical and beautiful series that is Harry Potter and I'm so happy to play a small part in this discovery. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449234727i/17254719._SX540_.jpg\" class=\"gr-hostedUserImg\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cb\u003eJ.K. Rowling's\u003c/b\u003e, humour, incredible, imaginative and easily accessible writing skills makes reading HP is as easy as...\u003cb\u003e“Swish and flick.”\u003c/b\u003e \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"10024032622645292111\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n class=\"friendReviews elementListBrown\" \u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"section\"\u003e\n      \n\n\u003cdiv id=\"review_139643694\" class=\"review\" itemprop=\"reviews\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Review\"\u003e\n  \u003clink itemprop=\"url\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/139643694\" /\u003e\n    \u003ca title=\"Adam\" class=\"left imgcol\" href=\"/user/show/1394221-adam\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Adam\" src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1269213228p2/1394221.jpg\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"left bodycol\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"reviewHeader uitext stacked\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/139643694?book_show_action=false\"\u003eSep 03, 2014\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Adam\" class=\"user\" name=\"Adam\" href=\"/user/show/1394221-adam\"\u003eAdam\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"did not like it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003edid not like it\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"did not like it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"did not like it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"did not like it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"did not like it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\n\n        \n\n\n          \u003cdiv class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/1394221-adam?shelf=childrens\"\u003echildrens\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/1394221-adam?shelf=fantasy\"\u003efantasy\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer139643694\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer15169979986456650471\"\u003eAwful in every way. The whole book is centered on lame, even deplorable ideas. First, it divides people into the wizardly and the non-wizardly in a class system. That's a fairly lame idea already, but other than deriding some of the snobby elitists among the wizardly class, it is itself ridiculously elitist, presenting its only non-wizardly people as an overblown, idiotic parody of middle class small-mindedness, conformity, and materialism, and making the elevation into the wizard class an\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText15169979986456650471\" style=\"display:none\"\u003eAwful in every way. The whole book is centered on lame, even deplorable ideas. First, it divides people into the wizardly and the non-wizardly in a class system. That's a fairly lame idea already, but other than deriding some of the snobby elitists among the wizardly class, it is itself ridiculously elitist, presenting its only non-wizardly people as an overblown, idiotic parody of middle class small-mindedness, conformity, and materialism, and making the elevation into the wizard class an unequivocally good thing. Second, it makes the magical into the mundane. Otherworldly and magical things, things beyond the everyday, are trivialized by transposing them into a world of magic shops and wizard schools essentially no different from non-magic shops and non-wizard schools. (It doesn't help that all the magical things are stock elements, with absolutely no originality or imagination.)\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eOutside its center of lameness, the book fails in all its basic storytelling elements. It's written in a completely standardized kids-book style, full of simplistic exaggerations, stock phrases, and twee comments from the narrator. Even if that style didn't irritate me with its obviousness and simplification, it's utterly indistinct here: the words have no verve. It does nothing of note to create suspense, excitement, pathos, vivid imagery, or anything else. And the dialogue is flat and unnatural, lacking any distinct voices.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eSimilarly, all its characters are cliches—the know-it-all girl, the goofy, good-hearted guy, the classist snob, etc.—that are given no definition or nuance beyond their stereotypes. Actually, they're so vague that they lack even the definiteness of their stereotypes. The villains are given still less: Snape is mean and punishes kids unfairly, Voldemort is evil and kills people, and that's it. And the characters' personality and feelings are related in the most simplistic ways. Harry Potter himself is just a cliched cipher of wish-fulfillment, the mistreated kid with no friends who's really the most special of all kids and destined for greatness.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThe overarching narrative is still another cliche: a journey away from home, in which kids learn and grow, and a move into an upper-class world full of possibilities and glamor and excitement. Within that, everything is just more lame cliches of school life and childhood friendships. There's also the kids being tested, doing some of that learning and growing, by foiling an evil plot. But the evil plot is painfully contrived (especially the ridiculous bit where all the characters conveniently get to show what they're good at—blech), so undeveloped that it barely registers, and carrying no weight. It also revolves around the ultimate cliche of misdirection: the person you least expect did it! And he's a non-character, defined only by being nervous and stuttering enough to be the person you'd least expect.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eFinally, Quidditch is the stupidest sport ever.\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"15169979986456650471\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n          \u003c/span\u003e\n        \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n      \u003cdiv class=\"reviewFooter uitext buttons\"\u003e\n          \n\n\u003ctr class=\"no_border feedFooterReview\" id=\"update_comment_stuff_Review139643694\"\u003e\n  \u003ctd colspan=\"2\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"updateActionLinks\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"right flag\" rel=\"nofollow\" id=\"flag_link139643694\" title=\"Flag this review as inappropriate.\" href=\"/flagged/new?resource_id=139643694\u0026amp;resource_type=Review\u0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone\"\u003eflag\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\n\n\n\n      \u003cspan class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_139643694'\u003e\u003ca id=\"like_count_review_139643694\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"/rating/voters/139643694?resource_type=Review\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"likesCount\"\u003e16 likes\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003cspan class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca id=\"like_action_review_139643694\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-like-container-id=\"like_container_review_139643694\" ref=\"like\" class=\"jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink\" data-remote=\"true\" data-method=\"post\" href=\"/rating?count_on_right=false\u0026amp;format=json\u0026amp;lc=16\u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=10\u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=139643694\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review\"\u003eLike\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca id=\"commentLink_139643694\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"comment_form_for(\u0026#39;review\u0026#39;, 139643694, true, \u0026#39;\u0026#39;); return false;\"\u003e10 comments\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/review/show/139643694?book_show_action=false\u0026amp;from_review_page=10\"\u003esee review\u003c/a\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n    \u003cdiv id='comments_for_review_139643694' style='display: none;'\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment'\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"loadingLink\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/review/139643694/comments?reverse=true\"\u003eView all 10 comments\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv id=\"comment_144859024\" class=\"brown_comment\"\u003e\n  \u003cdiv class=\"xhr_comment_photo\"\u003e\n    \t\u003ca alt=\"Adam\" href=\"/user/show/1394221-adam\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1269213228p1/1394221.jpg\" alt=\"1394221\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003cdiv class=\"xhr_comment_body\"\u003e\n    \u003ca style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"/user/show/1394221-adam\"\u003eAdam\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer2512568237985526160\"\u003e\u003ci\u003eAlana wrote: \"I mean not to be rude, but do you think this book may have sounded like it was meant for kids because it was meant for kids\"\u003c/i\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI'm not sure\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText2512568237985526160\" style=\"display:none\"\u003e\u003ci\u003eAlana wrote: \"I mean not to be rude, but do you think this book may have sounded like it was meant for kids because it was meant for kids\"\u003c/i\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI'm not sure which part of my review you're referring to. The bit about the prose style? I like a lot of children's literature, so it's not like I'm fundamentally predisposed to dislike anything meant for kids.\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"2512568237985526160\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n    \u003cbr/\u003e\n\n    \u003cspan class=\"xhrCommentFooter greyText\"\u003e\n      Dec 26, 2015 10:57AM\n    \u003c/span\u003e\n\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003cdiv class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv id=\"comment_153433741\" class=\"brown_comment\"\u003e\n  \u003cdiv class=\"xhr_comment_photo\"\u003e\n    \t\u003ca alt=\"The Maivy\" href=\"/user/show/57133867-the-maivy\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/u_25x33-ccd24e68f4773d33a41ce08c3a34892e.png\" alt=\"U 25x33\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003cdiv class=\"xhr_comment_body\"\u003e\n    \u003ca style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"/user/show/57133867-the-maivy\"\u003eThe Maivy\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer6604671321289721634\"\u003eThis book was meant to draw in younger children. class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"\u003e\u003ca id=\"like_action_review_1759926364\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-like-container-id=\"like_container_review_1759926364\" ref=\"like\" class=\"jsLike like_it gr-button href=\"/rating?count_on_right=false\u0026amp;format=json\u0026amp;lc=16\u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=10\u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1759926364\u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review\"\u003eLike\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingAnimation\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"loadingError\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003ca id=\"commentLink_1759926364\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"comment_form_for(\u0026#39;review\u0026#39;, 1759926364, true, \u0026#39;\u0026#39;); return \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n    \u003cdiv id='comments_for_review_1759926364' style='display: none;'\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1759926364' comment...\u003c/textarea\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\n      \u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"elementListBrownSeparator\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"friendReviews elementListBrown\" \u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"section\"\u003e\n      \n\n\u003cdiv id=\"review_690902253\" class=\"review\" itemprop=\"reviews\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Review\"\u003e\n  \u003clink itemprop=\"url\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/690902253\" /\u003e\n    \u003ca title=\"Cristina\" class=\"left imgcol\" href=\"/user/show/22978411-cristina\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Cristina\" src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465333252p2/22978411.jpg\" /\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"left bodycol\"\u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"reviewHeader uitext stacked\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/690902253?book_show_action=false\"\u003eJun 17, 2016\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Cristina\" class=\"user\" name=\"Cristina\" href=\"/user/show/22978411-cristina\"\u003eCristina\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003eit was amazing\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n          \u003cspan class=\"greyText\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\n          \u003ca class=\"lightGreyText\" title=\"Hardcover 9788478886548\" href=\"/book/show/15868.Harry_Potter_y_la_piedra_filosofal\"\u003ereview of another edition\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\n        \n\n\n          \u003cdiv class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=favorites\"\u003efavorites\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=20th-century\"\u003e20th-century\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=wwc-uk\"\u003ewwc-uk\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer690902253\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer17966107228630293335\"\u003eAviso antes de empezar que esta no es una reseña especial ni el relato de cómo comenzó mi amor por la literatura. Sólo es la historia de alguien que, como tantos otros de mi generación, tuvo la maravillosa fortuna de crecer junto a Harry. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eNo estoy segura de si Harry llegó a mi vida el día que cumplí nueve o diez años. Unos amigos de mis abuelos, a sabiendas de cuánto me gustaba leer, me regalaron por mi cumpleaños mi más que manoseado ejemplar de Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal, diciendo que\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText17966107228630293335\" style=\"display:none\"\u003eAviso antes de empezar que esta no es una reseña especial ni el relato de cómo comenzó mi amor por la literatura. Sólo es la historia de alguien que, como tantos otros de mi generación, tuvo la maravillosa fortuna de crecer junto a Harry. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eNo estoy segura de si Harry llegó a mi vida el día que cumplí nueve o diez años. Unos amigos de mis abuelos, a sabiendas de cuánto me gustaba leer, me regalaron por mi cumpleaños mi más que manoseado ejemplar de Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal, diciendo que el libro se había puesto de moda y que parecía que gustaba bastante. La verdad sea dicha, mi capacidad crítica era nula en esos momentos y leía todo lo que caía en mis manos, así que no le di la menor importancia. Hasta que comencé a leer y Harry me atrapó.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eNo soy consciente de cómo llegaron a mis manos ni el segundo ni el tercer libro, pero sé que devoré uno detrás de otro y que sufrí una tremenda decepción cuando me acerqué a la papelería de al lado de mi casa y me dijeron que el cuarto libro no estaba publicado. ¡Fue la primera vez que tuve que esperar a que se publicase un libro!\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eEsperé mi carta de Hogwarts con ahínco durante un par de años. Soñaba con llegar allí y vivir las aventuras que vivía Harry. Tengo el recuerdo de estar en mi habitación haciendo cábalas sobre mi edad y la de los personajes para saber si coincidiría o no con ellos en clase. \u003cs\u003eSí, siempre he sido un poco fantasiosa.\u003c/s\u003e \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eHarry Potter me descubrió un mundo repleto de magia, amistad y fantasía. A día de hoy, mis ejemplares de la saga siguen teniendo un lugar privilegiado en mis estanterías, a pesar de tener los lomos desgastados y las páginas amarillentas de tanto leerlos. Soy consciente de que no son libros perfectos y de que la saga tiene contradicciones y errores, pero nada me ha hecho llorar como la muerte de Fred o la de Dobby. Y ningún otro libro me impulsó a escribir, tanto como lo hizo este.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eGracias a Harry, me adentré en el mundo del fanfiction donde, no sólo mejore muchísimo como escritora y me animé a publicar (de manera amateur), sino que conocí a personas maravillosas que forman parte de mi vida desde hace años, enriqueciéndola de muchísimas formas. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eLa saga de Harry Potter me sigue haciendo soñar tanto hoy como la primera vez que me adentré en la normalidad del número 4 de Privet Drive. Brindemos para que «El niño que vivió» siga viviendo mucho tiempo.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eGracias por todos estos años, J.K.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eUna orgullosa Huffie.\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"17966107228630293335\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n          \u003c/span\u003e\n \u003cdiv class=\"elementListBrownSeparator\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"friendReviews elementListBrown\" \u003e\n    \u003cdiv class=\"section\"\u003e\n      \n\n\u003cdiv   \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/1115256584?book_show_action=false\"\u003eMar 19, 2015\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Evey\" class=\"user\" name=\"Evey\" href=\"/user/show/19222970-evey\"\u003eEvey\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003eit was amazing\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"it was amazing\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\n\n        \n\n\n          \u003cdiv class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=favorites\"\u003efavorites\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=2014-paranormal-fantasy-challenge\"\u003e2014-paranormal-fantasy-challenge\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer1115256584\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer11501826006914105822\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 magic stars\u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eReading this made me happy. It was like going back to my childhood, when I first heard (and read) about Harry Potter. I was/am one of the lucky ones from the \"Potter generation\", and I have nothing but good things to say about the story, the world, the characters that J. K. Rowling created.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThis is exactly the type of book children and young teens should read. Nowadays, mainly girls, are reading stuff that are marketed for older and more mature readers, focused on topics they know no\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText11501826006914105822\" style=\"display:none\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 magic stars\u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eReading this made me happy. It was like going back to my childhood, when I first heard (and read) about Harry Potter. I was/am one of the lucky ones from the \"Potter generation\", and I have nothing but good things to say about the story, the world, the characters that J. K. Rowling created.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThis is exactly the type of book children and young teens should read. Nowadays, mainly girls, are reading stuff that are marketed for older and more mature readers, focused on topics they know nothing about yet and probably shouldn't read about due to not being ready to get the grasp of it and a whole, objective vision of their own after reading said stories (for example, \"BDSM\" stuff that in reality is not BDSM but a \"how-to-be-abused-by-a-bastard\" guide... You know which book I'm talking about. And that one is not the only book with abuse being glamorized.) \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThis book, even though it's not the \u003ci\u003every best\u003c/i\u003e written book ever, focuses on the value of friendship, family and team work. It portrays flawed, yet strong characters. And not only male characters, but also female, which is currently hard to find nowadays. Women, girls, are normally being depicted as weak and needy, whose only purpose is to \u003cs\u003eserve\u003c/s\u003e \u003ci\u003elove\u003c/i\u003e a man in order to find their lives complete, and whose happiness depends solely and exclusively in said man. And to get him, in many books friendship is torn apart just for the sake of getting their love interest. In my opinion, we're sending the wrong message to young girls. Many do believe that, indeed, they need a boyfriend to be happy. That if they don't have one, their worth is less or there's something wrong with them. Society itself promotes the message that if you're a woman and you don't get a man, you failed at life. All I can ask myself is \u003ci\u003ewhy\u003c/i\u003e.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIn the other hand, Harry Potter shows brave characters, all in its own particular way. Characters that through each book continue to grow and develop. That's why I recommend anyone, young or not, to read these books. At least for the happy old times!\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003ePS: Proud Ravenclaw here! :D\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"11501826006914105822\" href=\"#\" \u003cdiv class=\"reviewHeader uitext stacked\"\u003e\n        \u003ca class=\"reviewDate createdAt right\" itemprop=\"publishDate\" href=\"/review/show/19022754?book_show_action=false\"\u003eAug 31, 2009\u003c/a\u003e\n\n      \u003ca title=\"Brad\" class=\"user\" name=\"Brad\" href=\"/user/show/1022982-brad\"\u003eBrad\u003c/a\u003e\n\n        rated it\n        \u003cspan class=\" staticStars\"\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003ereally liked it\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p10\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan title=\"really liked it\" size=\"15x15\" class=\"staticStar p0\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\n          \u003cspan class=\"greyText\"\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u0026middot;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003e\n          \u003ca class=\"lightGreyText\" title=\"Hardcover 9780747532699\" href=\"/book/show/848654.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone\"\u003ereview of another edition\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\n          \u003cdiv\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"greyText\"\u003eRecommended to Brad by: \u003c/span\u003e\n      Michelle Svenson\n  \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n\n          \u003cdiv class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=fantasy\"\u003efantasy\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=youth\"\u003eyouth\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=read-to-bronte\"\u003eread-to-bronte\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer19022754\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer9988306040948695037\"\u003eIs there any point in saying anything about \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e anymore? Not really. Not as far as critiques go. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIf I were to delve into some interesting critical analysis of an issue raised in \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eThe Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e, or take a critical look at Rowling's authorship, then maybe...but most everything that can be said about liking or disliking the book, about its excellence or its shabbiness has been said.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eAnd while I feel I may eventually take a stand for those who appreciate\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText9988306040948695037\" style=\"display:none\"\u003eIs there any point in saying anything about \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e anymore? Not really. Not as far as critiques go. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eIf I were to delve into some interesting critical analysis of an issue raised in \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eThe Philosopher's Stone\u003c/a\u003e, or take a critical look at Rowling's authorship, then maybe...but most everything that can be said about liking or disliking the book, about its excellence or its shabbiness has been said.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eAnd while I feel I may eventually take a stand for those who appreciate \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/1077326.J_K__Rowling\" title=\"J.K. Rowling\"\u003eJK Rowling\u003c/a\u003e's world of witches and wizards, who think that these books occasionally achieve real excellence, who connect emotionally to any one of the impressive characters she has drawn, I officially concede my inability to do so here.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eBut I will make this observation: those who equate the Twilight series to the Harry Potter series for entertainment value, quality of storytelling, cultural influence, influence on literacy, or the writing chops of their authors are people you do NOT want to be taking book advice from.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eThere is more than something in the \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_\" title=\"Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling\"\u003eHarry Potter\u003c/a\u003e series worth reading. I couldn't find anything worth reading in the works of \u003ca href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/941441.Stephenie_Meyer\" title=\"Stephenie Meyer\"\u003eStephenie Meyer\u003c/a\u003e (except that it had been published).\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"9988306040948695037\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return false;\"\u003e...more\u003c/a\u003e\n\n          \u003c/span\u003e\n        \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n      \u003cdiv class=\"reviewFooter uitext buttons\"\u003e\n          \n\n\u003ctr class=\"no_border feedFooterReview\"     \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer1580627511\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer18120588904220374130\"\u003eOkay so I think I'm the only person standing on this earth who has not read the Harry Potter series yet, and here, this is my first ever book for J K Rowling. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI have watched the movies so many times, however. I can quote the movies actually, and I am very glad that for this book, the movie follows exactly everything in details. The book isn't relatively long anyway, not many fillers were there, it was a sequence of ongoing adventures, which by the way was the best part about it. But anyway I bel\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText18120588904220374130\" style=\"display:none\"\u003eOkay so I think I'm the only person standing on this earth who has not read the Harry Potter series yet, and here, this is my first ever book for J K Rowling. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eI have watched the movies so many times, however. I can quote the movies actually, and I am very glad that for this book, the movie follows exactly everything in details. The book isn't relatively long anyway, not many fillers were there, it was a sequence of ongoing adventures, which by the way was the best part about it. But anyway I believe that contributed to the fact that the storyline isn't altered all that much in the movie. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eAfter failing at picking a good story book to read for what feels like forever, I have picked this up because I know you can never go wrong with HP, and that could be the truest thing I have said in my life. And though I knew the story, I was still very thrilled reading through the pages of the book. \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003eTo say this is a page turner is an understatement, I enjoyed everything about it. The writing however sounded a bit middle grade, but I am so excited to see the character development along the series, as well as how she, Ms. Rowling, grew as a writer (mind you, not that there was anything wrong with this one) \u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003ca data-text-id=\"18120588904220374130\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"swapContent($(this));; return class=\"uitext greyText bookshelves\"\u003e\n            Shelves:\n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/30679152-melissa?shelf=favourites\"\u003efavourites\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/30679152-melissa?shelf=read-2014\"\u003eread-2014\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/30679152-melissa?shelf=rereads\"\u003erereads\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/30679152-melissa?shelf=read-2015\"\u003eread-2015\u003c/a\u003e, \n              \u003ca class=\"actionLinkLite\" href=\"/review/list/30679152-melissa?shelf=booktubeathon-2015\"\u003ebooktubeathon-2015\u003c/a\u003e\n          \u003c/div\u003e\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\n\n        \u003cdiv class=\"reviewText stacked\"\u003e\n              \u003cspan id=\"reviewTextContainer914602602\" class=\"readable\"\n              \u003e\n            \n\u003cspan id=\"freeTextContainer6414244365993193282\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e First reread (2nd time reading overall) 28/10/14 - 30/10/14 \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003eDo I really need to write a review? Harry Potter will forever and always be my favourite series. I literally cannot think of any series that could come close. Every single page is just perfection. I have not one bad thing to say about the entire series. I cannot wait to reread the rest in this series.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cb\u003e Second reread (3rd time reading overall) 5/08/15 - 6/08/15 \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003eUgh. Once again, just perfect. Second time reading this in less than a year.\u003c/span\u003e\n  \u003cspan id=\"freeText6414244365993193282\" style=\"display:none\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e First reread (2nd time reading overall) 28/10/14 - 30/10/14 \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003eDo I really need to write a review? Harry Potter will forever and always be my favourite series. I literally cannot think of any series that could come close. Every single page is just perfection. I have not one bad thing to say about the entire series. I cannot wait to reread the rest in this series.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cb\u003e Second reread (3rd time reading overall) 5/08/15 - 6/08/15 \u003c/b\u003e\u003cbr\u003eUgh. Once again, just perfect. Second time reading this in less than a year. No regrets. \u003cbr\u003eHarry Potter is perfection.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1438956952ra/15774571.gif\"
